titleStmt.title:
Lady Betty Berkley finding in the Author's
Room some Verses unfinish'd, underwrit a
Stanza of her own, with Raillery upon him whih
gave Occasion to This Ballad. Aug: 1702.

lg.l: To Ye Tune of the Cutpurse.
Once on a Time, as old Stories rehearse,
A Friar would needs show his Talent in Lattin;
But was sorely put to't in the midst of a Verse,
Because he could find no Word to come pat in.
||Then all the Place,
||He left a Void Space,
And so went to bed in a desperate Case.
When Behold the next morning, a Wonderfull Riddle,
He found it was strangely fill'd in the Middle.
Chor: {Let Censur'ing Criticks then think what they list on't,
Who whould not Write Verses with such an Assistant.

2.
This put me the Friar into an Amazement
For he Wisely consider'd it must be a Sprite
That came thrô the Key-hole, or in at the Casement,
And it needs must be One that could both read & Write:
||Yet he did not know
||If it were friend or Foe;
Or whether it came from Above, or Below.
Howe'er it was Civil in Angel or Elf,
For he ne'er could have fill'd so well of himself.
Chor: Let Censur'ing &c
om.

3.
Even so Master Doctor had puzzled his Brains,
In making a Ballad, but was at a Stand,
He had mix'd little Wit, with a great deal pains,
When he found a New help from Invisible hand.
||Then good Doctor Swift
||Pay Thanks for the Gift,
For You freely must own You were at a dead Lift;
And tho some Malicious Young Spirit did do't
You may know by the hand it had no Cloven Foot.
Chor: Let Censur'ing Criticks then think what they List on't
Who would not write Verses wtḥ such an Assistant?
